conclusion: Four identical wooden blocks (A, B, C, D) on a smooth horizontal surface. Blocks B and C are connected by a light spring. A horizontal force F is applied to block B. All blocks accelerate with the same acceleration. We need to find the static friction force on block D.

Block D is stacked on top of block C. Block A is stacked on top of block B. Blocks B and C are connected by a spring. Force F is applied horizontally to block B. All blocks move with the same acceleration.

Define variables: m = mass of each block, a = acceleration of the entire system, F = external force applied to block B, F_spring = force exerted by the spring, F_D = static friction force on block D (what we're looking for).

premise: Block B experiences the external force F and spring force F_spring pulling it toward block C.
conclusion: Total force on B: F - F_spring = m·a

premise: Block C experiences spring force F_spring pulling it toward block B.
conclusion: Total force on C: F_spring = m·a

premise: Block D is stacked on top of block C and accelerates with it.
conclusion: Total force on D: F_D = m·a
Block A is stacked on top of block B and accelerates with it. Total force on A: F_A = m·a (not directly relevant to our question).

premise: From analysis of block C: F_spring = m·a
conclusion: From analysis of block B: F - F_spring = m·a

premise: Substituting F_spring = m·a into F - F_spring = m·a
Since the force on block D must provide its acceleration: F_D = m·a
